content_scrubbed:
Teaching abroad in general is a pretty good situation to be in, whether it[.] TEFL or at International Schools. You still typically get paid decently well enough to save/travel, get free housing/allowance, etc. By far, teaching at an International School is better. Better perks, better pay, more opportunities for career-climbing, PD, better housing, and lots and lots of time off (about 12-14 weeks a year). 

If you aren't officially certified, you won't even be considered for a real accredited International School. There are schools in China and in Korea that *call* themselves International Schools, but really they're just private schools for wealthy Koreans/Chinese. You may qualify for those - I have a friend teaching History in a Chinese "International School," despite only having a Liberal Arts B. A., zero teaching experience, and zero certification. 

But In real International Schools, jobs are competitive, and typically they want you to have a real state teacher certification (or equivalent in another country), and few years of certified classroom experience in your home country before you're a competitive or desirable candidate. 

So if you're not certified, the route you're most likely to take will be a TEFL teacher route as an Education Major. This means you're a bit more desirable a candidate than say a recent college grad with no Education degree or specialization in Ed, but you probably aren't as competitive as someone with a CELTA and several years of teaching experience. 

If you aren't getting certified, I would focus on making yourself the most desirable candidate for the TEFL world - this includes a CELTA, perhaps a Master[.] in TESOL, etc. I wouldn't listen to the people saying you're competitive candidate right now - with no actual teaching experience and an Ed Major, you're certainly hireable, but not in the top tier of candidates by any means.
